  <div class="stackedit__html"><h1 id="the-basics-of-provable-security">2. The Basics of Provable Security</h1>
<p>Edgar Allan Poe was not only an author, but also a cryptography enthusiast. He once wrote, in a discussion on the state of the art in cryptography:<sup class="footnote-ref"><a href="#fn1" id="fnref1">1</a></sup></p>
<blockquote>
<p>“Human ingenuity cannot concoct a cipher which human ingenuity cannot resolve.”</p>
</blockquote>
<p>This was an accurate assessment of the cryptography that existed in 1841. Whenever someone would come up with an encryption method, someone else would inevitably find a way to break it, and the cat-and-mouse game would repeat again and again.</p>
<p>Modern 21st-century cryptography, however, is different. This book will introduce you to many schemes whose security we can <strong>prove</strong> in a very specific sense. The code-makers <em>can</em> win against the code-breakers.</p>
<p>It’s only possible to <em>prove</em> things about security by having <em>formal definitions</em> of what it means to be “secure.” This chapter is about the fundamental skills that revolve around security definitions: how to write them, how to understand &amp; interpret them, how to prove security using the <em>hybrid technique</em>, and how to demonstrate insecurity using attacks against the security definition.</p>
<h2 id="how-to-write-a-security-definition">2.1 How to Write a Security Definition</h2>
<p>So far the only form of cryptography we’ve seen is one-time pad, so our discussion of security has been rather specific to one-time pad. It would be preferable to have a vocabulary to talk about security in a more general sense, so that we can ask whether <em>any</em> encryption scheme is secure.</p>
<p>In this section, we’ll develop two security definitions for encryption.</p>
<h3 id="what-doesn’t-go-into-a-security-definition">What <em>Doesn’t</em> Go Into a Security Definition</h3>
<p>A security definition should give guarantees about what can happen to a system in the presence of an attacker. But not all important properties of a system refer to an attacker. For encryption specifically:</p>
<ul>
<li>We don’t reference any attacker when we say that the Enc algorithm takes two arguments (a key and a plaintext), or that the KeyGen algorithm takes no arguments. Specifying the types of inputs/outputs (<em>i.e.</em>, the “function signature”) of the various algorithms is therefore not a statement about security. We call these properties the <strong>syntax</strong> of the scheme.</li>
<li>Even if there is no attacker, it’s still important that decryption is an inverse of encryption. This is not a security property of the encryption scheme. Instead, we call it a <strong>correctness</strong> property.</li>
</ul>
<p>Below are the generic definitions for syntax and correctness of symmetric-key encryption:</p>
<p><strong>Definition 2.1 (Encryption syntax)</strong><br>
<em>A <strong>symmetric-key encryption (SKE) scheme</strong> consists of the following algorithms:</em></p>

<li>KeyGen: <em>a randomized algorithm that outputs a <strong>key</strong> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="script">K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k \in \mathcal{K}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.73354em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.01445em;">K</span></span></span></span></span></span></em>.</li>

<p>The definition is written in terms of a probability because Enc is allowed to be a randomized algorithm. In other words, decrypting a ciphertext with the same key that was used for encryption must <em>always</em> result in the original plaintext.</p>

vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">c</span></span></span></span></span> <em>does satisfy the correctness property, but would not satisfy any reasonable security property.</em></p>
<h3 id="“real-vs-random”-style-of-security-definition">“Real-vs-Random” Style of Security Definition</h3>
<p>Let’s try to make a security definition that formalizes the following intuitive idea:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><em>“an encryption scheme is a good one if its ciphertexts look like random junk to an attacker.”</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>Security definitions always consider <strong>the attacker’s view</strong> of the system. What is the “interface” that Alice &amp; Bob expose to the attacker by their use of the cryptography, and does that particular interface benefit the attacker?<br>
In this example, we’re considering a scenario where the attacker gets to observe ciphertexts. How <em>exactly</em> are these ciphertexts generated? What are the inputs to Enc (key and plaintext), and how are they chosen?</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Key:</strong> It’s hard to imagine any kind of useful security if the attacker knows the key. Hence, we consider that the key is kept secret from the attacker. Of course, the key is generated according to the KeyGen algorithm of the scheme.<br>
At this point in the course, we consider encryption schemes where the key is used to encrypt only one plaintext. Somehow this restriction must be captured in our security definition. Later, we will consider security definitions that consider a key that is used to encrypt many things.</li>
<li><strong>Plaintext:</strong> It turns out to be useful to consider that the attacker actually <em>chooses</em> the plaintexts. This a “pessimistic” choice, since it gives much power to the attacker. However, if the encryption scheme is indeed secure when the attacker chooses the plaintexts, then it’s also secure in more realistic scenarios where the attacker has some uncertainty about the plaintexts.</li>
</ul>
<p>These clarifications allow us to fill in more specifics about our informal idea of security:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>*“an encryption scheme is a good one if its ciphertexts look like random junk to an attacker <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mo>…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ldots</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.12em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="minner">…</span></span></span></span></span> when each key is secret and used to encrypt only one plaintext, even when the attacker chooses the plaintexts.”</p>
</blockquote>
<p>A concise way to express all of these details is to consider <strong>the attacker as a calling program</strong> to the following subroutine:</p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><menclose notation="top bottom left right"><mtable rowspacing="0.6599999999999999em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><munder accentunder="true"><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>∈</mo><mo>∑</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="script">M</mi><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mo>:</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="true">‾</mo></munder></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi>k</mi><mo>←</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mtext>&nbsp;KeyGen&nbsp;</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi>c</mi><mo>:</mo><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mtext>&nbsp;Enc&nbsp;</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">return</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></menclose><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">

\quad k \leftarrow \Sigma . \text { KeyGen } \\ 
\quad c:=\Sigma . \text { Enc }(k, m)\\
\quad \operatorname{return} c \\ \hline

<p>A calling program can choose the argument to the subroutine (in this case, a plaintext), and see <em>only</em> the resulting return value (in this case, a ciphertext). The calling program <em>can’t</em> see values of privately-scoped variables (like <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> in this case). If the calling program makes many calls to the subroutine, a fresh key <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> is chosen each time.<br>
The interaction between an attacker (calling program) and this CTXT subroutine appears to capture the relevant scenario. We would like to say that the outputs from the CTXT subroutine are uniformly distributed. A convenient way of expressing this property is to say that this CTXT subroutine should have the same effect on <em>every</em> calling program as a CTXT subroutine that (explicitly) samples its output uniformly.</p>

<p>Intuitively, no calling program should have any way of determining which of these two implementations is answering subroutine calls. As an analogy, one way of saying that “foo is a correct sorting algorithm” is to say that “no calling program would behave differently if foo were replaced by an implementation of mergesort.”</p>
<p>In summary, we can define security for encryption in the following way:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><em>“an encryption scheme is a good one if, when you plug its</em> KeyGen <em>and</em> Enc <em>algorithms into the template of the CTXT subroutine above, the two implementations of CTXT induce identical behavior in every calling program.”</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>In a few pages, we introduce formal notation and definitions for the concepts introduced here. In particular, both the calling program and subroutine can be randomized algorithms, so we should be careful about what we mean by “identical behavior.”</p>
<p><strong>Example</strong><br>

<p><em>“an encryption scheme is a good one if, when you plug its</em> KeyGen <em>and</em> Enc <em>algorithms into the template of the EAVESDROP subroutines above, the two implementations of EAVESDROP induce identical behavior in every calling program.”</em></p>

<p><em>If these two implementations have the same effect on all calling programs (and indeed they do), then we would say that OTP satisfies this security property.</em></p>
<p>Is this a better/worse way to define security than the previous way? One security definition considers an attacker whose goal is to distinguish real ciphertexts from random values (real-vs-random paradigm), and the other considers an attacker whose goal is to distinguish real ciphertexts of two different plaintexts (left-vs-right paradigm). Is one “correct” and the other one “incorrect?” We save such discussion until later in the chapter.</p>
<h2 id="formalisms-for-security-definitions">2.2 Formalisms for Security Definitions</h2>
<p>So far, we’ve defined security in terms of a single, self-contained subroutine, and imagined the attacker as a program that calls this subroutine. Later in the course we will need to generalize beyond a single subroutine, to a <em>collection</em> of subroutines that share common (private) state information. Staying with the software terminology, we call this collection a <strong>library</strong>:</p>
<p><strong>Definition 2.3 (Libraries)</strong><br>
<em>A <strong>library</strong> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span> is a collection of subroutines and private/static variables. A library’s <strong>interface</strong> consists of the names, argument types, and output type of all of its subroutines (just like a Java interface). If a program <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span></span></span></span></span> includes calls to subroutines in the interface of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span>, then we write <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi><mo>⋄</mo><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A} \diamond \mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋄</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span> to denote the result of <strong>linking</strong> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span></span></span></span></span> to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span> in the natural way (answering those subroutine calls using the implementation specified in <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; We write <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi><mo>⋄</mo><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mo>⇒</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A} \diamond \mathcal{L} \Rightarrow z</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋄</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⇒</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.04398em;">z</span></span></span></span></span> to denote the event that program <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi><mo>⋄</mo><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A} \diamond \mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋄</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span> outputs the value <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">z</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.04398em;">z</span></span></span></span></span>.</em></p>
<p>If <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span> is a program that makes random choices, then the output of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi><mo>⋄</mo><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A} \diamond \mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋄</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span> is a random variable. It is often useful to consider probabilities like Pr[<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi><mo>⋄</mo><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mo>⇒</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A} \diamond \mathcal{L} \Rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋄</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⇒</span></span></span></span></span> true].</p>
<p><strong>Example</strong><br>
Here is a familiar library:</p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><menclose notation="top bottom left right"><mtable rowspacing="0.6599999999999999em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em" rowlines="solid none none none"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mtable rowspacing="0.6599999999999999em" columnalign="center" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><munder accentunder="true"><mrow><mtext>CTXT(</mtext><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>:</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="true">‾</mo></munder></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi>k</mi><mo>←</mo><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>0</mn></mstyle><mo separator="true">,</mo><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>1</mn></mstyle><msup><mo stretchy="false">}</mo><mi>λ</mi></msup></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi>c</mi><mo>:</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>⊕</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mtext>return&nbsp;</mtext><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></menclose></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
\def\arraystretch{1.5} 
\begin{array}{|l|} \hline 
\begin{array}{c} 
\qquad \mathcal{L} \\ 
\end{array} \\ \hline 
\underline{\text{CTXT(}m):} \\
\quad k \leftarrow \{\textcolor{brown}{0},\textcolor{brown}{1} \}^{\lambda} \\
\quad c:= k \oplus m \\ 
\quad \text{return } c \\ \hline 
\end{array}
</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 9.16em; vertical-align: -4.305em;"></span><span <p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><menclose notation="top bottom left right"><mtable rowspacing="0.6599999999999999em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em" rowlines="solid none none"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mtable rowspacing="0.6599999999999999em" columnalign="center" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>←</mo><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>0</mn></mstyle><mo separator="true">,</mo><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>1</mn></mstyle><msup><mo stretchy="false">}</mo><mi>λ</mi></msup></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>:</mo><mo>=</mo><mtext>CTXT</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mtext>return&nbsp;</mtext><mi>m</mi><mover><mo><mo>=</mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">?</mo></mover><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></menclose></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">

<p><em>You can hopefully convince yourself that</em></p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Pr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi><mo>⋄</mo><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mo>⇒</mo><mtext>&nbsp;true&nbsp;</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>λ</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{A} \diamond \mathcal{L} \Rightarrow \text { true }]=1 / 2^{\lambda} .
</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="mord mathrm">r</span></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋄</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⇒</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;true&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.14911em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.899108em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">λ</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p><em>If this <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span></span></span></span></span> is linked to a different library, its output probability may be different. If a different calling program is linked to this <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span></span></span></span></span>, the output probability may be different.</em></p>
<p><strong>Example</strong><br>
<em>A library can contain several subroutines and private variables that are kept static between subroutine calls. For example, here is a simple library that picks a string <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span></span></span></span></span> uniformly and allows the calling program to guess <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span></span></span></span></span>.</em></p>

<p><em>Our convention is that code outside of a subroutine (like the first line here) is run once at initialization time. Variables defined at initialization time (like <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span></span></span></span></span> here) are available in all subroutine scopes (but not to the calling program).</em></p>
<h3 id="interchangeability">Interchangeability</h3>
<p>The idea that “no calling program behaves differently in the presence of these two libraries” still makes sense even for libraries with several subroutines. Since this is such a common concept, we devote new notation to it:</p>
<p><strong>Definition 2.4 (Interchangeable)</strong></p>
<p><em>Let <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mtext>left</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_{\text{left}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; <p>This definition considers calling programs that give boolean output. Imagine a calling program / attacker whose only goal is to distinguish two particular libraries (indeed, we often refer to the calling program as a <strong>distinguisher</strong>). A boolean output is enough for that task. You can think of the output bit as the calling program’s “guess” for which library the calling program thinks it is linked to.</p>
<p>The distinction between “calling program outputs <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mtext mathvariant="monospace">true</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\texttt{true}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.55358em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord texttt">true</span></span></span></span></span></span>” and “calling program outputs <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mtext mathvariant="monospace">false</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\texttt{false}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.61111em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord texttt">false</span></span></span></span></span></span>” is not significant. If two libraries don’t affect the calling program’s probability of outputting true, then they also don’t affect its probability of outputting <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mtext mathvariant="monospace">false</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\texttt{false}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.61111em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord texttt">false</span></span></span></span></span></span>:</p>

<p><strong>Example</strong><br>
<em>Here are some very simple and straightforward ways that two libraries may be interchangeable. Hopefully it’s clear that each pair of libraries has identical behavior, and therefore identical effect on all calling programs.</em><br>
<em>Despite being very simple examples, each of these concepts shows up as a <strong>building block</strong> in a real security proof in this book.</em></p>

<h3 id="discussion-pitfalls">Discussion, Pitfalls</h3>
<p>It is a common pitfall to imagine the calling program <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span></span></span></span></span> being <em>simultaneously</em> linked to both libraries, but this is not what the definition says. The definition of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>≡</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_1 \equiv \mathcal{L}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; This is an especially important distinction when <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span></span></span></span></span> makes several subroutine calls in a single execution.</p>
<p>Another common pitfall is confusion about the difference between the algorithms of an encryption scheme (e.g., what is shown in Construction 1.1) and the libraries used in a security definition (e.g., what is shown in Definition 2.6). The big difference is:</p>
<ul>
<li>The algorithms of the scheme show a regular user’s view of things. For example, the Enc algorithm takes two inputs: a key and a plaintext. Is there any way of describing an algorithm that takes two arguments other than writing something like Construction 1.1?</li>
<li>The libraries capture the attacker’s view of of a particular scenario, where the users use the <em>cryptographic algorithms in a very specific way</em>. For example, when we talk about security of encryption, we don’t guarantee security when Alice lets the attacker choose her encryption key! But letting the attacker choose the plaintext is fine; we can guarantee security in that scenario. That’s why Definition 2.5 describes a subroutine that calls Enc on a plaintext that is chosen by the calling program, but on a key <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> chosen by the library.<br>
A security definition says that some task (<em>e.g.</em>, distinguishing ciphertexts from random junk) is impossible, when the attacker is allowed certain influence over the inputs to the algorithms (<em>e.g.</em>, full choice of plaintexts, but no influence over the key), and is allowed to see certain outputs from those algorithms (<em>e.g.</em>, ciphertexts).</li>
</ul>
<p>It’s <strong>wrong</strong> to summarize one-time secrecy as: “I’m not allowed to choose what to encrypt, I have to ask the attacker to choose for me.” The correct interpretation is: “If I encrypt only one plaintext per key, then I am safe to encrypt things even if the attacker sees the resulting ciphertext and even if she has some influence or partial information on what I’m encrypting, because this is the situation captured in the one-time secrecy library.”</p>
<h3 id="kerckhoffs’-principle-revisited">Kerckhoffs’ Principle, Revisited</h3>
<p>Kerckhoffs’ Principle says to assume that the attacker has complete knowledge of the algorithms being used. Assume that the choice of keys is the <em>only</em> thing unknown to the attacker. Let’s see how Kerckhoffs’ Principle is reflected in our formal security definitions.</p>
<p>Suppose I write down the source code of two libraries, and your goal is to write an effective distinguisher. So you study the source code of the two libraries and write the best distinguisher that exists. It would be fair to say that your distinguisher “knows” what algorithms are used in the libraries, because it was designed based on the source code of these libraries. The definition of interchangeability considers <em>literally every</em> calling program, so it must also consider calling programs like yours that “know” what algorithms are being used.</p>
<p>However, there is an important distinction to make. If you know you might be linked to a library that executes the statement “<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>←</mo><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>0</mn></mstyle><mo separator="true">,</mo><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>1</mn></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k \leftarrow \{\textcolor{brown}{0}, \textcolor{brown}{1}\}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">←</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">{</span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">1</span><span class="mclose">}</span></span></span></span></span>”, that doesn’t mean you know the actual <em>value</em> of k that was chosen at runtime. Our convention is that all variables within the library are privately scoped, and the calling program can learn about them only indirectly through subroutine outputs. In the library-distinguishing game, you are not allowed to pick a different calling program based on random choices that the library makes! After we settle on a calling program, we measure its effectiveness in terms of probabilities that take into account all possible outcomes of the random choices in the system.</p>
<p>In summary, the calling program “knows” what algorithms are being used (and how they are being used!) because the choice of the calling program is allowed to depend on the 2 specific libraries that we consider. The calling program “doesn’t know” things like secret keys because the choice of calling program isn’t allowed to depend on the outcome of random sampling done at runtime.</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Kerckhos’ Principle, applied to our formal terminology:</strong><br>
<em>Assume that the attacker knows every fact in the universe, except for:</em></p>
<ol>
<li><em>which of the two possible libraries it is linked to in any particular execution, and</em></li>
<li><em>the random choices that the library will make during any particular execution (which are usually assigned to privately scoped variables within the library).</em></li>
</ol>
</blockquote>
<h2 id="how-to-demonstrate-insecurity-with-attacks">2.3 How to Demonstrate Insecurity with Attacks</h2>
<p>We always define security with respect to two libraries — or, if you like, two library <em>templates</em> that describe how to insert the algorithms of a cryptographic scheme into two libraries. If the two libraries that you get (after filling in the specifics of a particular scheme) are interchangeable, then we say that the scheme satisfies the security property. If we want to show that some scheme is <em>insecure</em>, we have to demonstrate <strong>just one calling program</strong> that behaves differently in the presence of those two libraries.</p>

<p>I haven’t shown the Dec algorithm, because in fact there is no way to write one that satisfies the correctness requirement. But let’s pretend we haven’t noticed that yet, and ask whether this encryption scheme satisfies the two security properties defined previously.</p>
<p><strong>Claim 2.9</strong><br>
<em>Construction 2.8 does <strong>not</strong> have one-time uniform ciphertexts (Definition 2.5).</em></p>
<p><strong>Proof</strong><br>
To see whether Construction 2.8 satisfies uniform one-time ciphertexts, we have to plug in its algorithms into the two libraries of Definition 2.5 and see whether the resulting libraries are interchangeable. We’re considering the following two libraries:</p>

<p>To show that these two libraries are <strong>not</strong> interchangeable, we need to write a calling program that behaves differently in their presence. The calling program should make one or more calls to the CTXT subroutine. That means it needs to choose the input <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">m</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">m</span></span></span></span></span> that it passes, and it must make some conclusion (about which of the two libraries it is linked to) based on the return value that it gets. What <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">m</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">m</span></span></span></span></span> should the calling program choose as input to CTXT? What should the calling program look for in the return values?</p>
<p>There are many valid ways to write a good calling program, and maybe you can think of several. One good approach is to observe that bitwise-AND with <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; But the bitwise-AND of any string <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> with all <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\textcolor{brown}{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">1</span></span></span></span></span>s is just <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> itself. <h2 id="how-to-prove-security-with-the-hybrid-technique">2.4 How to Prove Security with The Hybrid Technique</h2>
<p>We proved that one-time pad satisfies the uniform ciphertexts property (Claim 1.3) by carefully calculating certain probabilities. This will not be a sustainable strategy as things get more complicated later in the course. In this section we will introduce a technique for proving security properties, which usually avoids tedious probability calculations.</p>

<p>The placement of the parentheses does not affect the functionality of the overall program, just like how splitting up a real program into different source files doesn’t affect its functionality.</p>

<p>It would not be too hard to directly show that ciphertexts in this scheme are uniformly distributed, as we did for plain OTP. However, the new hybrid technique will allow us to leverage what we already know about OTP in an elegant way, and avoid any probability calculations.</p>
<p><strong>Claim 2.13</strong><br>
<em>Construction 2.12 has one-time uniform ciphertexts (Definition 2.6).</em></p>

<h3 id="summary-of-the-hybrid-technique">Summary of the Hybrid Technique</h3>
<p>We have now seen our first example of the hybrid technique for security proofs. All security proofs in this book use this technique.</p>

<li>Proving security means showing that two particular libraries, say <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mtext>left</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_{\text{left}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; You must justify why each modification doesn’t affect the calling program (<em>i.e.,</em> why the two libraries before/after your modification are interchangeable).</li>
<li>As discussed in Section 2.2, simple things like inlining/factoring out subroutines, changing unused variables, changing unreachable statements, or unrolling loops are always “allowable” modifications in a hybrid proof since they have no effect on the calling program. As we progress in the course, we will see more kinds of useful modifications.</li>
</ul>

<p>For educational purposes, let’s try to repeat the steps of our previous security proof on this (insecure) scheme and <strong>see where things break down</strong>. <p>Here’s a more conceptual way to understand what went wrong here. The important property of OTP is that its ciphertexts look uniform <em>when the key is used to encrypt only one plaintext</em>. This “double OTP” variant uses OTP in a way that doesn’t fulfill that condition, and therefore provides no security guarantee. The previous (successful) proof was able to factor out some XOR’s in terms of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mtext>otp-real</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_{\text{otp-real}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.969438em; vertical-align: -0.286108em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.336108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">otp-real</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.286108em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> without breaking anything, and that’s how we know the scheme was using OTP in a way that is consistent with its security guarantee.</p>
<p>As you can hopefully see, the process of a security proof provides a way to catch these kinds of problems. It is very common in a hybrid proof to factor out some statements in terms of a library from some other security definition. This step can only be done successfully if the underlying cryptography is being used in an appropriate way.</p>
<h2 id="how-to-comparecontrast-security-definitions">2.5 How to Compare/Contrast Security Definitions</h2>
<p>In math, a definition can’t really be “wrong,” but it can be “not as useful as you hoped” or it can “fail to adequately capture your intuition” about the concept.</p>
<p>Security definitions are no different. In this chapter we introduced two security definitions: one in the “real-vs-random” style and one in the “left-vs-right” style. In this section we treat the <em>security definitions themselves</em> as objects worth studying. Are both of these security definitions “the same,” in some sense? Do they both capture all of our intuitions about security?</p>
<h3 id="one-security-definition-implies-another">One Security Definition Implies Another</h3>
<p>One way to compare/contrast two security definitions is to prove that one implies the other. In other words, if an encryption scheme satisfies definition #1, then it also satisfies definition #2.</p>
<p><strong>Theorem 2.15</strong><br>

<h3 id="one-security-definition-doesn’t-imply-another">One Security Definition Doesn’t Imply Another</h3>
<p>Another way we might compare security definitions is to identify any schemes that satisfy one definition without satisfying the other. This helps us understand the boundaries and “edge cases” of the definition.</p>
<p>A word of warning: If we have two security definitions that both capture our intuitions rather well, then any scheme which satisfies one definition and not the other is bound to appear <strong>unnatural and contrived</strong>. The point is to gain more understanding of the <em>security definitions themselves</em>, and unnatural/contrived schemes are just a means to do that.</p>
<p><strong>Theorem 2.16</strong><br>
<em>There is an encryption scheme that satisfies one-time secrecy (Definition 2.6) but not one-time uniform ciphertexts (Definition 2.5). In other words, one-time secrecy <strong>does not</strong> necessarily imply one-time uniform ciphertexts.</em></p>
<p><strong>Proof</strong><br>
One such encryption scheme is given below:</p>

<p>This scheme is just OTP with the bits <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>00</mn></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\textcolor{brown}{00}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span></span></span></span></span> added to every ciphertext. The following facts about the scheme should be believable (and the exercises encourage you to prove them formally if you would like more practice at that sort of thing):</p>
<ul>
<li>This scheme satisfies one-time one-time secrecy, meaning that encryptions of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">m_L</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.58056em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, for any <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">m_L</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.58056em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">L</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">m_R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.58056em; We can characterize the ciphertext distribution in both cases as “<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">λ</span></span></span></span></span> uniform bits followed by <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>00</mn></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\textcolor{brown}{00}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span></span></span></span></span>.” Think about how you might use the hybrid proof technique to formally prove that this scheme satisfies one-time secrecy!</li>
<li>This scheme does not satisfy the one-time uniform ciphertexts property. Its ciphertexts always end with <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>00</mn></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\textcolor{brown}{00}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span></span></span></span></span>, whereas uniform strings end with <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>00</mn></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\textcolor{brown}{00}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span></span></span></span></span> with probability 1/4. Think about how you might formallize this observation as a calling program /distinguisher for the relevant two libraries!</li>
</ul>
<p>You might be thinking, surely this can be fixed by redefining the ciphertext space as <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.05834em;">C</span></span></span></span></span></span> as the set of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda + 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.77777em; vertical-align: -0.08333em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">λ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.222222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span>-bit strings whose last two bits are <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>00</mn></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\textcolor{brown}{00}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span></span></span></span></span>. This is a clever idea, and indeed it would work. If we change the definition of the ciphertext space <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.05834em;">C</span></span></span></span></span></span> following this suggestion, then the scheme would satisfy the uniform ciphertexts property (this is because the <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mrow><mtext>ots</mtext><mi>Φ</mi><mtext>-rand</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_{\text{ots}\varPhi\text{-rand}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.336108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">ots</span></span><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathit mtight">Φ</span></span><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">-rand</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> library samples uniformly from whatever <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.05834em;">C</span></span></span></span></span></span> is specified as part of the encryption scheme).</p>
<p>But this observation raises an interesting point. Isn’t it weird that security hinges on how narrowly you define the set <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.05834em;">C</span></span></span></span></span></span> of ciphertexts, when <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.05834em;">C</span></span></span></span></span></span> really has no effect on the <em>functionality</em> of encryption? Again, no one really cares about this contrived “OTP +<span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="brown"><mn>00</mn></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\textcolor{brown}{00}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.64444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span><span class="mord" style="color: brown;">0</span></span></span></span></span>” encryption scheme. The point is to illuminate interesting edge cases in the <em>security definition itself!</em></p>

<ul>
<li><strong>Closure:</strong> for all <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="double-struck">G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a,b \in \mathbb{G}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.88888em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">G</span></span></span></span></span></span>, we have <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⊗</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="double-struck">G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a \otimes b \in \mathbb{G}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.66666em; <li><strong>Identity:</strong> there is a special <em>identity element</em> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="double-struck">G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e \in \mathbb{G}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; <p><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mo>⋆</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\star</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.46528em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">⋆</span></span></span></span></span> 2.11. Prove that if an encryption scheme <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\Sigma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">Σ</span></span></span></span></span> has <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="script">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mo>&lt;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="script">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">|\Sigma.\mathcal{K}| &lt; |\Sigma.\mathcal{M}|</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">∣</span><span class="mord">Σ</span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.01445em;">K</span></span><span class="mord">∣</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">∣</span><span class="mord">Σ</span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">M</span></span><span class="mord">∣</span></span></span></span></span> then it cannot satisfy onetime secrecy. Try to structure your proof as an explicit attack on such a scheme (<em>i.e.,</em> a distinguisher against the appropriate libraries).</p>
<p>The Enc algorithm of one-time pad is deterministic, but our definitions of encryption allow Enc to be randomized (<em>i.e.,</em> it may give different outputs when called twice with the same <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">m</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">m</span></span></span></span></span>). For full credit, you should prove the statement even for the case of Enc is randomized. However, you may assume that Dec is deterministic.</p>
<p><strong>Hint:</strong><br>
The definition of interchangeability does not place any restriction on the running time of the distinguisher/calling program. Even an exhaustive brute-force attack would be valid.</p>
<p>2.12. \quad m:=\sum \cdot \operatorname{Dec}\left(k_{1}, c_{1}\right) \\
\quad \text {return } m
\end{array}\\

<p>2.16. Formally define a variant of the one-time secrecy definition in which the calling program can obtain two ciphertexts (on chosen plaintexts) encrypted under the same key. Call it two-time secrecy.<br>
(a) Suppose someone tries to prove that one-time secrecy implies two-time secrecy. Show where the proof appears to break down.<br>
(b) Describe an attack demonstrating that one-time pad does not satisfy your definition of two-time secrecy.</p>
